Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Sprites Using High Temporal and Spatial Optical Imaging
Award.AbstractNarration: This collaborative project has the scientific objective of improving understanding of detailed physical processes associated with sprites as well as their potential impact on the mesosphere and the global electrostatic field. This will be accomplished by optical observations (images and spectra) with high spatial and temporal resolution. Summer field campaigns will be conducted on the NSF sponsored HIAPER aircraft to follow up a successful 2009 sprite observations campaign by the investigators. The observations will be analyzed and compared with various sprite models. Furthermore, collaboration with participants at Princeton University will involve laboratory streamer studies relevant to sprites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sprites are bright, short-lived electrical discharges in the 50-90 km altitude associated with lightning activity in the troposphere below. They typically lasts only 0.1 second, and since they can be very dynamic with luminous streamers going down and up high-speed imaging is required to investigating them. With support from this grant we have recorded sprites at 10,000 to 20,000 frames per second (fps).  The observations have been done in yearly 2 week field campaigns during the summer in the US mid-west where there is good lightning activity. In 2012, 2015, and 2017, we observed from the Langmuir Laboratory, New Mexico Tech, near Socorro, NM. In 2014 we used the Wyoming Infrared Observatory, University of Wyoming, on Jelm Mountain, WY.  In 2013 we observed from the NSF supported HIAPER aircraft flying above 40,000 feet out of Broomfield, CO. Flying above most of the atmosphere largely prevents scattering and absorption of blue light. The ground-based campaigns emphasized observations with good spatial resolution. For the airborne campaign we configured our images to record optical spectra.

We recently acquired imagers capable of recording at 100,000 fps, but weather has prevented good observations. However, we have verified that with favorable conditions sprites are bright enough for good data to be recorded at 100,000 fps or at even higher frame rates.


The primary science issues we have addressed relate to aspects of the electric discharge processes where imaging can provide key insights. The data analysis has also involved a number of collaborations with computer modelers to give more detailed insights into the processes involved and to address observations versus model predictions.  We give below 3 topics that have been addressed:

Splitting of sprite streamers.

Streamers are small (a few 100 m across) ionization fronts present during the initial phase of a sprite. In the images they are small balls of light moving up and down at velocities near 0.1 times the speed of light. In normal video (30 fps) or in photographs they appear as streaks of light across the images. To resolve them requires imaging at more than 5000 fps. Interestingly, we observe streamers to split into many sub-streamers in contrast to streamers at or near ground pressure which only rarely split into more than 2 sub streamers. This is of interest to the physics of electrical discharges, important to industrial applications and power distribution.  The splitting is thought to be caused by instabilities associated with the charge distribution across the ionization front. We are looking at the density scaled diameter of the streamers, which appears to be larger in sprites than in the laboratory, and the distance travelled between splits. The splitting process is very fast and cannot be resolved even at 20,000 fps. For this work we really need our new instrument capability of observation at 100,000 fps.

 Sprite glow and beads.

While streamers move rapidly up and down glow and beads are stationary optical features. They appear in the channels formed by the streamers. We have observed glow and beads at altitudes between 40 and 80 km altitude, and remarkably, glow and beads within a given streamer channel decay with the same time constant despite being 10s of km apart in altitude, and hence in very different ambient pressure. We have found that the reason is that the glow and beads are driven by the streamer channel current, which does not change with altitude. Further, the glow and beads are the result of the same physical process.

 Sprite spectra.

The optical emissions in sprites are almost exclusively from molecular nitrogen which emits both in the blue and red. The emissions are from collisions with ambient electrons. The electron energy needed to excite the emissions differs between the blue and the red, so the ratio of blue to red emissions can be used to estimate the energies of the electrons involved. Analysis of spectra recorded from the HIAPER aircraft clearly show that the electrons leading to streamer emissions are more energetic than those involved in glow and beads. Hence, streamers are associated with higher ambient electric fields. Further our analysis finds the observed spectra consistent with our model for the generation of sprite glow and beads.

  

Our work on this grant has been published in 11 journal publications, and we have made 20 presentations at various scientific meetings. The grant has supported 1 PhD graduate student. During our field campaigns undergraduate engineering students from Fort Lewis College, Durango, CO, have participated to give them research experience. Undergraduate students have also been participating in various aspects of equipment development and data analysis.
